ratings.comment: Simply, "meh." Class is a little more physics intensive than I expected as someone who has never taken an astro class, though that is to be expected. Not a lot of actual math you have to do, but you have to have a strong conceptual understanding of the physics. It's not the world's best class, but if you need a QR or a natural sciences, take it.

The class is straight forward and interesting, but she goes pretty fast. 3 midterms no final exam all online and can take anywhere between 9 to 1. do quizzes in lecture, but online/ can retake or wait till she puts answer on the board. In discussion had 4 projects all "group" projects. They honestly didn't connect to class content and were hard.

HORRIBLE. have never had a worse professor. everything you learn in lecture has nothing to do with the readings, which has nothing to do with the homework, and the homework has nothing to do with the section work. is basically is a figure out yourself with barely any guidance. The exam questions have nothing to do what is taught in lecture.

Prof Barger is super sweet and is obviously very passionate about astronomy. Her lectures can be a little dry sometimes, but lecture slides were always posted on canvas. The weekly homework is super important and helps a lot in getting ready for the midterms and tests. Also, the honors optional assignments were 3-4 easy, 1 page papers.

Amy is clearly knowledgeable and passionate about her field, but this didn't help her teach an intro-level class. She went through lectures way too fast and went into details far beyond a beginner's level (and what tests covered). Group projects were assigned that were equally complicated and in-depth, without helping you understand the essentials.

Professor Barger is clearly very knowledgable in her field, but this often made her lectures hard to understand. She went through them very quickly and rarely ever elaborated beyond what was on her slides. Discussions section activities and groups projects had little to no relevance to course content and it felt pointless to go. Exams were online.

Prof Barger goes way too fast through lecture as she tries to cram an enormous amount of information on complex subjects down your throat at breakneck speed. She then assigns an exam with THIRTY QUESTIONS as if we could feasibly cover all the course material that could possibly be on the exam. Way too intense for an intro course.

She is very knowledgeable about astronomy. She always tries to engage the class with videos and photos but I just found the content dry. There is a huge disconnect between the discussion activities and lectures. There were group projects that are worth a big part of your discussion grade, they are graded harshly and lowered my grade

Professor Barger is just kind of boring. She is really passionate about what she teaches and researches and you can tell that, but it isn't the most exciting class in the world. She teaches really well, but it is just so hard to pay attention in her classes

Ugh, don't take this class. I learned actually nothing, and the exams were very very hard. The class has a lot of busy work and the lectures give you minimal insight on exam questions. Just don't waste your time and please take something else.

Very difficult class to take asynchronously. Many difficult group projects. Amy seemed very nice from her pre-recorded lecture videos, however, the lectures were very boring which made it hard to follow. Do not take this class if you have no prior experience with physics even though it is not a prerequisite.

Extremely knowledgeable and cares about students. All of the content was very cool, but the lectures, homework, tests, and projects/papers were somewhat disconnected. Solid choice if you want something interesting but not too difficult.

The class was online and asynchronous and super easy. I never read the textbook once and only watched the videos at 1.5x-2x speed and got an A. This class just has a decent amount of busy work with short papers and group assignments but overall a pretty easy A. The professor is a little boring and talks slow but 2x speed on her videos helps.

This class was completely asynchronous which was honestly the best option. Each week consisted of about an hour of short video lessons, 20 minutes of homework, and either a group project or a writing assignment. The TA's did most of the teaching which wasn't a big deal. When she did teach, though, I found it confusing to follow along at times.

This class was frankly a waste of my time. They try and make you learn way to much information that makes the exams frankly impossible. The class had the ability to be interesting , relatively easy, and enjoyable, but ultimately I did not enjoy my time in this class and would recommend you do not take it.

Amy is very knowledgeable on the subject but lectures are often filled with information unrelated to the readings/exam material. That being said, her exams are all very fair if you just read the textbook. Her lectures are certainly not spectacular but if you do the readings and have good attendance you'll be just fine.

+ Passionate professor! Interesting class!! + 3 multiple choice midterms worth 60% of the grade. Fair questions. Practice exams handed out. - Online homework doesn't really reflect exam questions. - Wasteful discussion groups with irrelevant worksheets.
What should have been an easy A wasn't because Barger doesn't explain anything she teaches and she goes waaaaaaay too fast in her lectures

Amy is great. Really nice and passionate about space. Her lectures are interesting and she keeps the slides fairly concise, only including test-relevant info. Do not buy the textbook, I never opened it. If you show up to class everyday and look over the lecture slides a day or two before the test it will be a very easy and interesting class.

Prof Badger was super nice and super knowledgeable, but the lectures were pretty boring and you had to go to them for participation points. She goes through the PowerPoints insanely fast, and shes not the best lecturer. Tests arent that bad, but if you dont study you will not do well on them.

First two exams and all the material was very easy. Homework and readings are very easy. But the last few weeks before the final get exponentially harder to the point its impossible to comprehend. She clearly is smart and a good person but her lectures DO NOT prepare you for what to come on that final. Not what i expected. Final was near impossibl

Amy was a great professor who was able to explain all of the course information in-depth in an interesting way. This isn't a difficult class, but it's important to read the chapters if you want to guarantee you'll leave the class with a good grade. You're going to have a much better time in this class if you're actually interested in space.

Barger is awesome, very passionate about her field and it shows. Sometimes lectures got a little dry but I am pretty sure that was just the nature of the curriculum sometimes (103). Class was great overall, not too tough and very cool.

If youre interested in space, its definitely a good gen ed to take. The last third of the class is a bit difficult but nothing too bad. Keep up with the readings to get a good grasp on the subject. My discussion section kinda sucked because of the other students in there but I had Anthony as a TA and he is great. Attendance is mandatory.

Amy is a pretty straightforward professor. She does a great job being comprehensible and making the material a little more interesting with videos and examples. The course itself is not hard, I would say going to lecture is pretty crucial because the material isn't exactly a cakewalk to understand. The exams are easy, and virtually no homework.

She is very passionate about her profession and it shows in her lectures, she is energetic and well prepared. The class is fairly easy. There is a textbook with readings but if you go to lecture and take notes / pay attention, reading the textbook isn't necessary. Show up, put in work before the exams, and you will be fine.

This class isn't bad. Lectures supplemented the textbook so definitely stay up with reading but only 1 chapter a week takes less than 2 hours. Not super exciting but bearable and the tests aren't too difficult. Prof Barger isn't an exciting lecturer but this is a good class to get a Gen Ed out of the way and boost the gpa, just put in some work.

There is a good amount of reading in the class, but all of it (or the important stuff) is gone over in lecture which is nice. Also, it is very helpful to go to lecture, but tophat is used so if you miss a lecture or a few then you will be fine. Professor Barger also seems to really enjoy teaching and lectures were super fun.

Prof Barger is very sweet, intelligent and accomplished. But she cannot teach. Her lectures are boring, don't make sense, and too much at once. She just reads off the slides. Her exams are difficult, specific and this class is not an easy A! Textbook's confusing too. Unless you have a genuine passion or time to spare, don't take it. Disappointed :/

Barger seems nice but her lectures are boring. Powerpoint jumps back and forth between topics and has a lot of useless information not needed for the exams. Exams range from very specific questions to very general ones. Weekly homework quizzes online (super easy but time consuming). Not a good professor overall but good/enthusiastic researcher.

The class consists of 2 midterms (35 points ea) and then the final exam (50 pts). The first midterm is easy, the second midterm progressively more challenging and the final was incredibly hard. This class is not an easy A. You have to work hard and study in this class to do well.

Very interesting material. However, the class grew exponentially more difficult after the first semester. The tests are extremely specific and worth 70% of your grade, so it is difficult to get a good grade in this class unless you spend a lot of time studying. The final was awful.

I never like to blame the class/professor, but this class really tested my limits. Lectures are the worst I have had: they are poorly organized and she flies through them so quickly that you can't take notes. Tests are ridiculously specific with ambiguous wording and no curves. Avoid this class.
Good professor. Super smart! Like most UW professors teaching freshman classes, she is teaching something wayyyy below her pay grade. Go to lecture, read the textbook and you should get an A.

She is a very nice lady and I know she is very smart. However, not every smart person should be a teacher and A. Barger is one of those people. She loves to talk about herself and her adventures that have nothing to do with class. She reads off of slides in class and her slides are unorganized. But you have to go to lectures for credit...

Prof. Barger is a pretty good lecturer. You can tell she is extremely smart. I always found the lectures informative, even though this class has nothing to do with my major. There is a little bit of extra credit and the exams aren't awfully difficult. Weekly homework. Good way to fulfill a science requirement.

One of the worst lecturers I have had yet. Her lecture slides are so unorganized, it is nearly impossible to take notes. She has them on Top Hat, but it doesn't make it any easier to follow since she writes them in paragraph form and likes to jump from topic to topic at a ridiculous speed. If it weren't for participation, I wouldn't come to class.

Love Astronomy but this class with her was not the best. She reads off her slides so you don't need to go to lecture except for participation. Her questions on the exams are worded weirdly and the options all sound the same and sometimes she asks questions that she didn't talk about and are not in the textbook and believe me I read the textbook

Lectures hewed very close to the textbook material. About one-third of lecture time was taken up by tophat questions, too much in my opinion. Professor Barger missed several golden opportunities to incorporate relevant discoveries in astronomy that were widely reported during the class and would have brought the material to life.

I took an astronomy class in high school, so I found this class to be really easy. I imagine it would be more difficult if you had no experience with the subject. Tbh though, I'm not a science person, and I think if you just read the text book and go to class its very doable. Like, actually try and you'll be fine

I thought Prof Barger was hilarious and cute, and she really knows her stuff. However, pay attention to the grading criteria. There are only 3 tests(which can be kind of hard because they are only 30 questions), but there is another 30% total for HW, quizzes, etc. Make sure to get 100% in the 30% because it will save your life!

This class wasn't hard at all. You have to put in work to do well on the exams, but reading from the text book is not necessary. She is a very boring lecturer, as she just reads off her slides, so going to class isn't really mandatory. Make sure to go to discussion, they will give you feedback and insight on exams.

Terrible lecturer. She doesn't seem to know how to set up a presentation to the point where it is damn near impossible to take notes. She just puts paragraphs up on her slides and her topics are extremely disorganized. Tests are so short that a couple wrong drops your grade an entire letter. Would not recommend the teacher whatsoever.
Very detailed lecture!
Doesn't lecture on needed material. Goes on many tangents, lectures more history than astronomy.

In this Lab we worked in groups of two (or three) on computer simulations to complete packets to be turned in. There were occasional quizzes but were able to use the packets. The packets were clear and we were able to ask questions at any time and she readily helped us. One of the last days she let us make popcorn and eat it while we worked.

This class was great. It was a topics class, and the topic was cosmology. It was super interesting and professor Barger is great. As long as you read every week, you can pull an A, and an AB is probably really easy to get. I'd definitely recommend this class
very nice woman and can be helpful but there is too much information to comprehend and there is way too much work for a 3 credit class.  Very obscure information, hard to grasp

Her lectures are very clear. She's very friendly and helpful. Tests were fair, with all the material covered in lecture, even some of the questions taken directly from her powerpoints. Would definitely recommend.
Her lectures are clear and understandable. Shes a nice woman.

A nicer person overall, but a HORRIBLE professor! She doesnt believe in grade curves (which is ridiculous for ANY science course in my experience) There are 2 exams, weekly chapters, weekly quizzes, and really pointless observing exercise... too much work for just a 3 credit class.  I know others in Astro 103 with other professors that do 1/2 work.

Read 1 chapter a week, 2 midterms and a final and weekly quizzes in discussion that do not need to be studied for.  This class is easy as long as you read and go to lecture.  She uses powerpoint and puts the exact slides online.  Not hard to get an A in.

She actually asked these 2 girls in the back row of a 200 person lecture if they could please stop talking because it was distracting her.  Apart from more people in the class and having more expected of you (she specifially says she is NOT going to teach you everything you need to know, READ THE TEXTBOOK), it's highschool all over again.
Take this class if you want to be treated like you're in kindergarten.  Prof. talks down to you.
